description: From Middle English comprehenden, from Latin comprehendere (“to grasp”), from the prefix com- + prehendere (“to seize”).

verbs.description: comprehend (third-person singular simple present comprehends, present participle comprehending, simple past and past participle comprehended)

entries.meaning: (now rare) To include, comprise; to contain. [from 14th c.]
examples: In the second century of the Christian Æra, the empire of Rome comprehended the fairest part of the earth, and the most civilized portion of mankind.

entries.meaning: To understand or grasp fully and thoroughly. [from 14th c.]
